imagingbook.pub.geometry.mappings

Class Mapping

  • java.lang.Object
    • imagingbook.pub.geometry.mappings.Mapping
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BilinearMapping, LinearMapping, RippleMapping, SphereMapping, TwirlMapping

    public abstract class Mapping
extends Object
implements Cloneable
    2013-02-02: changed to use the returned new point of applyTo(Point2D), not relying on side effect. 2014-04-19: modified to work with ImageAccessor. 2015-12-10: added isInverse() method.

        public Point2D[] applyTo(Point2D[] pnts)
        Applies this mapping to all points in the pnts array.
        Parameters:
        pnts - array of original points.
        Returns:
        an array of modified points.

      • applyTo

        public void applyTo(ij.process.ImageProcessor ip,
                    InterpolationMethod im)
        Destructively transforms the image in "ip" using this geometric mapping and the specified pixel interpolation method. TODO: this should not be here (geometry only)?
        Parameters:
        ip - target image to which THIS mapping is applied.
        im - interpolation method.

      • applyTo

        public void applyTo(ij.process.ImageProcessor source,
                    ij.process.ImageProcessor target,
                    InterpolationMethod im)
        Transforms the "source" image to the "target" image using this geometric mapping and the specified pixel interpolation method. Source and target must be different images!
        Parameters:
        source - input image (not modified).
        target - output image (modified).
        im - interpolation method.

      • applyTo

        public void applyTo(ImageAccessor sourceAcc,
                    ImageAccessor targetAcc)
        Transforms the source image (contained in "srcInterpol") to the "target" image using this geometric mapping and the specified pixel interpolator.
        Parameters:
        sourceAcc - accessor to the source image
        targetAcc - accessor to the target image
